Award.AwardTitle: Designing Novel Tunable Colloids Via Inverse Statistical Mechanics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1701843
PI: Torquato, Salvatore

The design of many advanced materials relies on the ability to devise building blocks, such as colloids and polymers, that interact with each other in specific ways to self-organize and form materials with novel electronic, mechanical or optical properties. Scientists and engineers predict this process by specifying an interaction potential between the building blocks and then computing the material structure and its properties that arise from self-organization. This award will support theoretical and computational research to discover new materials using the opposite or "inverse" approach. In the inverse approach, designers start by specifying the desired material structure and properties and then discover the required interactions between the building blocks that will produce the desired structure The project will emphasize finding interactions that can be realized experimentally by combining currently available colloidal interactions. Hence, the results should provide guidance to experimentalists to fabricate designer colloids. The inverse approach will provide new ways to control the degree of order/disorder of the material to achieve novel properties, which will accelerate the discovery of materials by design. The project will support training of graduate students and will provide opportunities for undergraduates to participate in research. Algorithms resulting from the research will be made freely available to researchers and will be used to enhance student education.

This award supports theoretical and computational research for materials discovery by inverse statistical-mechanical optimization techniques. Inverse statistical-mechanical methods will be formulated and applied to optimize many-particle interactions to achieve targeted colloidal structures with desired physical properties. Inverse statistical-mechanical methods allow for a new mode of thinking about the structure and physical properties of condensed phases of matter and are ideally suited for materials discovery by design. However, inverse techniques thus far have considered potential functions that were not constrained to be experimentally realizable. A central aim of this project is to optimize both isotropic and anisotropic pair interactions that are constrained by what can be achieved by a combination of currently available colloidal repulsive and attractive interactions, including excluded-volume repulsions, depletion interactions, Van der Waals forces, forces induced by functionalizing the particle surface, and electrostatic repulsions. Potential functions will be "tailored" to achieve robust self-assembly of unique targeted crystal, liquid and amorphous states of matter, including exotic disordered hyperuniform systems. Examples of novel materials that will be designed include those for photonics and color sensing applications, negative or vanishing thermal expansion coefficients, tunable negative and positive Poisson ratios, optimal transport, electromagnetic and mechanical properties, and mesoporous solids for applications in catalysis, separations, sensors and electronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have formulated and applied inverse methods to optimize many-particle interactions to achieve novel targeted colloidal structures and physical properties. Such theoretical and computational methods, pioneered by the P.I., allow  for  a  new  mode  of  thinking  about  the structure and physical properties of condensed phases of matter and are ideally suited for materials discovery by design. However, inverse techniques applied in the recent past considered potential functions that were not constrained to be experimentally realizable. A central aim was to optimize both isotropic and anisotropic pair interactions that are constrained by what can be achieved by a combination of currently available colloidal repulsive and attractive interactions (excluded-volume repulsions, depletion interactions, Van der Waals forces, forces induced by functionalizing the particle surface, electrostatic repulsions, etc.). Potential functions were "tailored" to achieve the robust self-assembly of unique targeted crystal, liquid and amorphous states of matter, including exotic disordered hyperuniform systems. Examples of novel materials that were designed include disordered materials for photonics and color sensing, materials with negative or vanishing thermal expansion coefficients, materials with tunable negative and positive Poisson ratios, materials with optimal transport, electromagnetic and mechanical properties, and mesoporous solids for applications in catalysis, separations, sensors and electronics.

The intellectual merit of the project is its transformational approach, which integrates inverse statistical mechanics with colloidal physics for the purpose of designing materials with tunable structures and physical properties. This long-term endeavor could revolutionize the manner in which novel materials are discovered and fabricated in the future. The proposed research will lead to a deeper understanding of self-assembly and provision of a unified theoretical underpinning for this technologically and scientiﬁcally important  field. Indeed, our "designer" potentials are expected to lead to materials that possess varying degrees of disorder, thus extending the traditional idea of self-assembly to incorporate not only crystalline structures but noncrystalline ones, such liquids and amorphous systems. This extension includes the elucidation of exotic disordered hyperuniform states of matter and their generation via colloidal systems. Finally, our work will have the far-reaching benefit of providing guidance to experimentalists to fabricate optimized interactions for designer colloids.

This is a multidisciplinary project that links the materials science, engineering, applied mathematics (optimization), and statistical and condensed-matter physics communities. Unifying these different perspectives could offer great rewards to these communities. The work has great technological relevance, as evidenced by the formation of recent start-up companies based on these ideas.

The P.I. has  influenced significantly the education of undergraduate and graduate students at Princeton in the various departments in which he is associated. The P.I. incorporated his research topics into both undergraduate and graduate curricula. The P.I. helped train highly qualified graduate students to think critically in order to succeed in the highly technical world we live in today. Undergraduates were also be involved in the P.I.'s research through Junior projects and Senior theses. The P.I. recruited underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students to carry out the proposed research.

Numerical codes and data will be made publicly available at the P.I.'s web site. The results of this work will continue to be widely disseminated in the scientific literature and in presentations around the world.
